thread.title: Newcastle North constituency General Election results 2017: Full standings, MP and reaction

author: Simon Meechan
title: Newcastle North constituency General Election results 2017: Full standings, MP and reaction

organizations.name: putting north of england people first party

text:
Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
This page provides full information about the Newcastle North constituency including candidates standing in the General Election 2017 , history of the seat and 2015 results. 
The interactive tool and information will be updated to show General Election 2017 results once the vote count is declared. 
The polls close at 10pm on Thursday, June 8 and results start being declared around midnight, with Sunderland and Newcastle usually among the first constituencies in the country to announce. 
This page will be updated as soon as the constituency in question has declared. Read More What are the results in my constituency? 
Enter your postcode below to find out more details on your constituency. Which parties and candidates standing in Newcastle North 
Labour - Catherine McKinnell Catherine McKinnell (Photo: Newcastle Chronicle) 
In seven years as an MP for Newcastle North, Catherine McKinnell has been a Shadow Education Minister, a Shadow Minister for Treasury, a Shadow Attorney General and a Shadow Solicitor General. 
Born in Denton , she studied politics and history at Edinburgh University and worked as an employment minister for a large Newcastle-based firm. 
She has criticised Take That star Gary Barlow for his tax affairs and accused Theresa May of “paranoia” for suggesting the EU is trying to interfere in the General Election. 
Mrs McKinnell has backed campaigns to ban junk food adverts before 9pm. She lives in Gosforth. 
JS*60835342 
Conservatives - Duncan Crute Newcastle East Conservative candidate Duncan Crute 
Newcastle businessman Duncan Crute will stand in Newcastle North, after running in Newcastle East two years ago. 
He has his own tailoring company, and previously ran a marketing consultancy for six years. 
Mr Crute is from Newcastle and promises to promote Newcastle North as a “great place to live.” He also says he will work with business, industry and commerce to boost employment. He pledges to deliver “cost effective” public services to vulnerable people. 
UKIP - Tim Marron Tim Marron, UKIP 
Timothy Marron, is running for UKIP in Newcastle North. 
The lifelong Newcastle resident spent most of his career running his own shops, starting with a cycle store and later a small chain of newsagents. 
He also stood in Newcastle North in 2015. 
Liberal Democrats - Anita Lower Coun. Anita Lower 
Standing again in Newcastle North is Anita Lower, the leader of the opposition on Newcastle City Council, where she represents the Lib Dems in Castle Ward. 
The councillor has worked in local Government for more than two decades, and was deputy leader of the city council before 2011. 
Her party says the “Brexit obsessed” Conservative Government is failing to provide the schools, hospitals and social care Newcastle deserves. 
A key policy is to fight what they call the Conservative’s “damaging approach” to Brexit and have dubbed Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership of the Labour party as “hapless”. 
Green Party - Alison Whalley Alison Whalley 
Another candidate returning for 2017 after standing in 2015 is Alison Whalley. She joined the Green Party in 2006. 
Alison supports a “well-funded” NHS with no more cuts or privatisation. She also wants university tuition fees scraps and no new grammar schools to be built. 
The Green Party candidate is calling for a Brexit which protects workers’ rights, the countryside and will encourage green jobs. 
She would also like to see the voting age lowered to 16. 
Putting North of England People First Party - Brian Moore 
Brian Moore is standing for the Putting North of England People First Party. What was the result in Newcastle North in 2015? 
Catherine McKinnell won with 20,689 votes, taking a 46% share. 
The Conservatives came second, with 23%, while UKIP took 17%. The Lib Dems won 10% of the vote and the Green Party took 3%. Read More
